headline: DOJ charges two Chinese nationals with an 'extensive' hacking campaign
subHeadline: Guests: James Daniel Jordan, Julian Epstein, Michael Pillsbury, Ethan Bearman, Robert Shibley, Jason Nichols, Mark Steyn

utterances.speaker: TUCKER CARLSON, HOST
utterances.sentences: Good evening and welcome to “Tucker Carlson Tonight.” Just a couple weeks from now, Democrats will take control of the House of Representatives. But before that happens, one final battle remains in Congress. It's over the wall we've been promised along our border with Mexico. For two years, Democrats and their allies in the Republican leadership have worked hard to keep that wall from being built. They're still working to prevent it just five days before Christmas.  The thinking is if they can delay the funding just a few more weeks, the wall will never be built. Killing the wall, of course, would be a big political win for the Left. There's no question about that, so congratulations.  But there are other considerations too like what about America? Why shouldn't we have secure borders? Pretty soon, Democrats will have to explain that to the country. Congressman Jim Clyburn of South Carolina took a stab at it today on CNN. Here's how it went.

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CORRESPONDENT, CNN
utterances.sentences: But why wouldn't a wall help improve security at the border?

utterances.speaker: REP. JAMES ENOS CLYBURN, D-S.C.
utterances.sentences: Well, because we think if the wall is 10 feet high, they'll get a 12-foot ladder. That's just simple arithmetic to us.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Ah, the 12-foot ladder argument, feels like we've heard that before from both parties. Jeb Bush used to drop the ladder argument at fundraisers in Palm Beach, people would smirk knowingly, "Yes, 12-foot ladders."   Only dumb people believe in walls. As Congressman Clyburn said, it's simple arithmetic. Walls don't work. They never will. That's why nobody builds them anymore. Oh, but wait. In fact, plenty of countries still build walls. Some of those nations are allies of ours, countries we strongly support and heavily subsidize. They build walls because walls work exceedingly well. Nothing works better, in fact, and everybody knows that. So, in some ways, Clyburn is behind the curve here still trying to make a fact-based argument, even a ludicrous one. Most Democrats are far beyond that now, into the realm of the metaphysical.   The Right Reverend, Luis Gutierrez, who is also a Democratic Congressman from Illinois, made the theological case against walls today, as he questioned Homeland Security Secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen. Gutierrez noted that people who support walls hate Jesus. It's that simple. Watch.

utterances.speaker: REP. LUIS VICENTE GUTIERREZ, D-ILL.
utterances.sentences: The majority on this committee must think you're doing a fantastic job because they've ordered this hearing so that you could come before us and look tough and remorseless just in the time for the holidays.  It is repugnant to me and astonishing to me that during Christmas, to call them the holiday seasons to be ex - inclusive, but during Christmas because the majority always wants to just call it Christmas that during Christmas, a time in which we celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ, a Jesus Christ who had to flee for his life with Mary and Joseph, thank God there wasn't a wall that stopped him from seeking refuge in Egypt.   Thank God that wall wasn't there, and thank God there wasn't an administration like this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Trump's worse than Pharaoh. See, Jesus hated walls. It's right there in the scriptures in the book of Obama, Chapter Six, Verse 13, and all the people said Amen. Can I get a hallelujah? How does a public official respond to a sermon like that? Well watch Secretary Nielsen try to respond. And as you do, pay special attention to The Right Reverend, Gutierrez, as she talks. Watch.

utterances.speaker: KIRSTJEN MICHELE NIELSEN, SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY
utterances.sentences: A policy of family separation would mean that any family that I encountered in the interior, I would separate. It would mean that any family that I found at a port of entry, I would separate. It would mean that every single family that I found illegally crossing, we would separate. We did none of those. What we did do is uphold the laws that Congress has passed and we prosecuted those who choose to come here illegally.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well when you ask questions and then don't stick around to hear the answers, people might start to suspect that you're not really interested in learning anything. And, of course, they're not interested.   People who support open borders do so out of self-interest, more money, more voters, but also on faith. They just know they're right. And they know for a fact that you're evil. It's obvious. Well maybe they're right, maybe they are good people, and you're irredeemably sinful. But that's not enough. Winning on virtue alone is not how our system works. You can only make people shut up and obey for so long. You could certainly silence them for a while. You can bully them into submission by calling them racists or throwing fake Bible verses at them. But that's only a short-term fix. At some point, in a democracy you have to convince them. And that starts by answering their questions.  Why not a wall? Nothing else has worked. There are likely more than 20 million foreign nationals living illegally in America right now. They're all using fraudulent federal ID. They're making a mockery of this country and our laws. It's totally dysfunctional. It's disgraceful. Everybody knows that.  Trump, whatever his faults, took the problem seriously. He promised a border wall. In the end, he did not deliver on that. That's on him. But instead of proposing a better idea or even acknowledging the seriousness of what is a legitimate crisis, the Left decided to pretend that everything is fine, and you're a bigot if you disagree. That's on them.   They may not know it yet. But by winning the last election and stopping the border wall, the Left just inherited responsibility for one of the biggest problems we, as a country, face. What is their problem and their plan now? Congressman Jim Jordan is a Republican representing Ohio right in the middle of all this, and he joins us tonight. Congressman, thanks a lot for coming on. So, the obvious question--

utterances.speaker: REP. JAMES DANIEL JORDAN, R-OH
utterances.sentences: You bet, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --as we have the final debate over the wall during the final hours of the Republican Congress--

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --why now? Why two years later?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll be - you're right. We should have done it earlier. We should have done it in March on the big Spending Bill we told American people we would.  Then we said, "No, no. We're going to do it in September." Didn't do it then on that spending bill. Then we said, "We'll do it on December 7." No, we didn't do then. Then we said, "We'll do it on December 21st." We did it tonight in the House. I mean just a few minutes ago, it passed. Even though, last week in the Oval Office, Nancy Pelosi said the House can't get the votes to pass a border security wall, funding for a border security wall, we just did a few minutes ago. Got 217 votes, I think the Democrats had a 185.  So, we just passed it in the House. That's step one. It now goes back to the Senate, and we'll see what happens from there. But we need to stand firm on this because, as - as you said, as the President said, this is a central promise we made to the voters in 2016.  This is our last best chance to do what everyone knows is just good common sense. Everyone, but Democrats, I should say, knows is good common sense.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I think it's fair for the rest of us to press a little deeper and ask well, why didn't it happen? I mean you're absolutely right. It should have happened and you probably would have preferred it had happened earlier but it didn't and--

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: We pushed for it to happen earlier, yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --right, right. I remember. But it didn't. And that means that people prevented it from happening. Obviously, Speaker Ryan was one of them. Who else, just so the rest of us can keep score?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Well it - look, it's always easier. I mean to do something that really counts and has lasting value, lasting meaning, it's never easy. So, one good thing (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, it's hard, for sure.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: --well exactly. So, anything worth doing is always difficult. But Congress always has a way of trying to take the least resistant route and do the easy thing. So, that's why it happened, I think, most often. But--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well wait, but - but hold on, I mean, look, and I know you were for it. But the tax bill was definitely hard. There was a lot of opposition to it. And the leadership just decided we're getting this done, that - that--

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's not something that Trump ran on or there was broad public support for it. But they wanted it and they got it done and they worked really hard, came on this show, made the case for it.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: You're - you're right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They didn't do that with the wall. And why? I'm just - I - again, I think it's fair to know since you're on the inside and we're not--

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --who prevented that?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Well I don't know anyone prevented it. But I think the intensity was more for the tax and tax cuts than it was for replacing and repeal - repealing and replacing Obamacare and building the border security wall. I think you're right about that. But there's some intensity today. We've been pushing. And like I said, we just passed a bill that puts $5 billion for a border security wall and that is a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: --good first step.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Amen to that. Congressman, thanks very much for coming on for that update. I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: You bet, Tucker, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Julian Epstein is a former Chief Counsel to the Democratic side of the House Judiciary Committee, and a longtime guest on this show. He joins us tonight. Julian, thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: JULIAN EPSTEIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: Thank you (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, I don't know what's going to happen. I'm assuming. I mean it's pretty late in the process that this is not going to happen. So, Democrats will say, you know, and Pelosi will say, we make good on our promise to stop the wall. OK, great. But then there's the day after that when you have, by Yale's estimate, over 20 million people here illegally using fake IDs. It's - it's out of control. What's the plan at that point to secure the border, the Democrats' plan?

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I think, well, let's talk about good faith. I mean I think you're ask - big question you're asking Representative Jordan is, were the Republicans a good faith? President Trump famously told the Mexican President that he didn't really care about the wall in a conversation that was caught by U.S. Intelligence.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's all true.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: The Republicans have been in control for two years now.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I couldn't agree more.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Why haven't they passed the thing?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I - look, I mean I just I--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: It's just--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --you don't need to - you don't need to--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, is this something--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --convince me to that.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --is this an issue they like to tell your viewers and their voters that they're for but it's just--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. I--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --symbolic like a mirage (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I think Paul Ryan--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --would like to leverage the enthusiasm and the donations of ordinary Republicans to win, and then subvert their will on behalf of his donors once he gets there. I agree--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well, so you're being honest. So, you're--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --with you there.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: being honest now that you're saying (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm being - well, I mean I'm not - I don't work for anybody, you know, but--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --yes, you're being honest. That's right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --but - but--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, let's talk about good faith on the Democrats' part--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --which is what you asked about. I think the Democrats have to say in unequivocal terms, we are completely against open borders. We are for - against illegal immigration. We are for legal immigration. Now, they've done that. In the past, Democrats have voted $40 billion for border security, they've - including, 700 miles of fencing and walls. Schumer is on record doing that. Donald Trump's position has changed from 2,000 miles of border wall to 700 miles of border wall. There's actually - actually consensus for physical security, border secure - border security, physical security, a wall, fencing, where it makes sense, not where it doesn't. Remember, two-thirds of the border area is controlled, either is owned by the states or owned by private individuals.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Even if you got all the funding done today, you're going to be tied up in court for 10 years on eminent domain legal challenges--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --on your ability to do this. But, more importantly, I think the wall is not--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wait, but hold on (ph), we just spent - just to put it in context, it's $5 billion for this wall as a start. We just spent, I think--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --good thought (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --$967 billion on a farm bill that literally gives tax dollars to the nieces and nephews of farmers for reasons that no one can explain to me. It's the most wasteful--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Definitely (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's disgusting, OK. And so, it's not--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: We're - we're in agreement.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --in this whole idea, it's too expensive, which is like such a transparent lie, it's not even worth addressing.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: No, no, I didn't say expensive.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think you were but--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --here's what I'm so struck by. Rather than make like a - an adult argument, we're getting Gutierrez lecturing us about Jesus.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Let me make an adult argument.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And - wait, hold on, and then Speaker of the House lecturing us about Jesus. Now, I'm pro-Jesus but like the partial-birth abortion caucus is lecturing me about Jesus because I mean, you know what I mean? It's insulting, actually.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, let me try to make an adult argument. I - I think it is political symbolism. I think it is something that the Trump campaign threw out in election time. And the reason I say that is because if you were serious about illegal immigration, which I think Democrats and Republicans ought to be, you would go after things that were going to make a difference. The primary cause, the primary suction tube of illegal immigration is visa overstays. Most people come here. They come on visas and they overstay their visas. And going after visa overstays will be far more than well (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, I - I couldn't agree more. And even if we verify (ph)--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --secondly (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I'm - I'm with you on that too.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --well let's go let's if (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No. But, look, it's a - it's a given, I agree.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --if you want to go - if you--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But what's - what's wrong with the wall?

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --but if you're serious--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But I just don't understand, look, those are all components. We're in total agreement. But the wall works in a bunch of different countries. It works famously on Israel's border with Egypt. But it - we claim it won't work here. It's such a lie. Everyone knows it's a lie.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: We--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why not just say it works? And let's just try it. I mean what's wrong with that? I'm missing it.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, where the wall makes sense I'm in complete agreement. We ought to do it. I don't think we had to do it 2,000 miles because many of those areas are completely impractical. They're mountain - they're incredibly mountainous. They're waterways. There's a complete--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's fine. I need that (ph).

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --there's plenty of places. So, we already do have border security. We do - already do have physical--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But what we have - can we both agree that--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: ---security.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and a lot of our illegal immigration comes from visa overstays. I understand that. But--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Most of it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --yes, right. But there's--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Most of it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --still millions of people who snuck over the border and still living here. So, why wouldn't you reassure the American people that we can all calm down and focus on a smart immigration policy that's, you know, emotionally decelerated from where you're now? People feel like it's out of control because it is.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I think well it's getting better. We had 300,000 border apprehensions last year, which is the lowest since '74.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It gets (ph) relatively speaking--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, the number of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --but it's still huge (ph).

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --the number of immigrants coming across the Southern border is way, way down.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Hundreds of thousands. That's way beyond (ph)--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: 300,000. Used to be - used to be--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK (ph)--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --three quarters a mil around (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just saying like that's much bigger than the city I grew up in. So--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --like that's a lot of people. Why not just--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: But it's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --wall it off and then we can have a rational conversation?

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, let's try and go back to this adult conversation, if we can. I agree there ought to be physical security in places that it makes sense, not where it doesn't make sense. I don't think the two parties are engaged in that kind of conversation right now. But that's - that's point one. Point two is the real problems here are not the border crossing. The real problems are visa overstays as we just talked about. Second one is employers. The reason why undocumented immigrants stay here--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --is because of employers. If Republicans and, I think, Democrats should be here as well, if they're so serious about this problem, why is it that they - they don't do things that will upset the business community like--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I - really you're - look, you're--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --employer sanctions.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --preaching to the choir--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: OK?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --completely. I think just--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: OK. But - but so there's a cynical--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --to see the activist Left--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --there's a cynicism--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --aligned with rapacious employers looking to exploit labor is a little bit stunning. That's what Republicans have always done. And now, all like the drones on the progressive side, or the intersectional sound, are like, "Yes, we're on the side of Amazon hiring cheaper labor." What?

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: So, we're - we're making a little bit of progress here, I think.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I think physical security where it makes sense, not where it doesn't, go after visa overstays, employer sanctions. The last point I would make to you is that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're almost out of time, here anyway (ph)--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --I don't think Mexico is the enemy here. Most of the - most of the illegal immigration that occurs on the Southern border is Central America, not Mexicans. And more than half of the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. But Mexico I mean if we're coming on as the (ph)--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --illegal is coming from Central (ph) America. But Mexican - Mexico actually--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --has a rather effective border security system.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But they've encouraged illegal immigration into this country--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: They've actually deported hundreds of thousands of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. They - they're pretty painful (ph) it's telling--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --Central Americans back to Central America.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --people how to sneak across the border so that that doesn't seem like they're--

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I - I think Mexico could--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --worth of an (ph) ally.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --conceivably be much more of an ally--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It could. It could. Hopefully we look forward (ph).

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --than it gets credit for (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Julian, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: EPSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you. California Democrats have been very proud of the new sanctuary state law. Now, a man released from prison, thanks to that law, apparently, killed two people. Trace Gallagher has the details on this unfolding story. Trace?

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Tucker, in the span of a few hours on Monday, police say Gustavo Garcia-Ruiz carried out 11 crimes, including killing a stranger and shooting at others before he was killed during a high-speed police chase. Authorities think Garcia-Ruiz also killed another man a day earlier. Last week, Garcia-Ruiz was arrested in Central California for being under the influence of drugs. When ICE learned he was in jail, they placed an immigration detainer on him asking deputies to notify them before releasing him. But under SB 54, California's sanctuary law, because the suspect wasn't being held on a felony, law enforcement is prohibited from honoring ICE detainers. ICE says, "This is an unfortunate and extremely tragic example of how public safety is impacted with laws or policies limiting local law enforcement agencies' ability to cooperate with ICE." And here's the gut kick. Garcia-Ruiz is a known, convicted, violent criminal, armed robbery, assault with a deadly weapon, repeatedly deported, etcetera. But under SB 54, none of that can be used to notify immigration agents. Here's the Tulare County Sheriff.

utterances.speaker: MIKE BOUDREAUX, TULARE COUNTY SHERIFF
utterances.sentences: That tool has been removed from our hands. And because of that, our County was shot up by a violent criminal that could have easily been prevented had we had the opportunity to reach out to our fellow counterparts.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Sheriff says he doesn't want to enforce immigration laws. He just wants violent criminals off the streets. Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Trace Gallagher for us. Thank you very much, Trace. Well, France is still burning tonight over efforts to impose a climate change agenda there. So needless to say, some in our Congress are anxious to do the same thing here, Jeff Flake, specifically, but others. We'll give you details after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Secretary of Defense, General - General James Mattis announced today he'll be leaving his post, quitting in February, after two years on the job. In his resignation letter, Mattis pointed toward policy disagreements he has with the President. He addressed the President directly in the letter writing, "Because you have the right to have a Secretary of Defense whose views are better aligned with yours, I believe it is right for me to step down from my position." The announcement came as something of a surprise. It also came shortly after the President's equally-surprising announcement. He's withdrawing U.S. troops from Syria, a deeply unpopular decision among permanent Washington. Mattis reportedly opposed that withdrawal as well, as well as a potential drawdown of American forces in Afghanistan. In a statement on Twitter, the President said this. "General Mattis was a great help to me in getting allies and other countries to pay their share of military obligations. A new Secretary of Defense will be named shortly. I greatly thank Jim for his service!" Well it may seem surprising that the President is breaking with one of his top advisors but there's another way to look at it. President Trump was told the U.S. could defeat ISIS and then leave Syria, once it did. The U.S. did that. Now, everyone in Washington is demanding he stay in Syria to counterbalance Russia and Iran. Last year, the same people told him that sending troops back to Afghanistan would greatly improve things in that country. That turned out to be completely false. The situation there seems worse than ever. And, of course, for two years, the President has been told that if he'd just be patient, he'd have his border wall. How did that turn out? He apparently is not paying heed to their advice anymore.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: THE CHINA THREAT.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The Administration today issued a strong condemnation of a major foreign power that routinely hacks American infrastructure, steals national secrets, technology, personal information in huge quantities. The Director of the FBI called this country the greatest long-term threat to America's wellbeing. Russia, oh sorry, excuse me. China, misread that, for more than two decades now, of course, it has always been China, America's greatest geopolitical rival. You wouldn't know that though from watching television. Even this week, with this new news about China, there's only one foreign power on the radar considered a threat. You know what it is.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER CHARLES CUOMO, ANCHOR, CNN
utterances.sentences: The Russians exploited a massive backdoor into the foundation of our democracy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Moscow's attack on American democracy.

utterances.speaker: TONY ROMM, THE WASHINGTON POST
utterances.sentences: The work by Russian agents to try to destabilize American democracy.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, HOST, CNN
utterances.sentences: It's everything you need to know about the threat to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: DAVID RICHMOND GERGEN, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: The long-term damage is going to be to weaken our democracy.

utterances.speaker: ELISE JORDAN, MSNBC ANALYST
utterances.sentences: You have Republicans who are silent and seemingly OK with this kind of attack on our democracy.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: These people are so stupid it's amazing they're employed. Michael Pillsbury, not stupid, and employed, Director of the Center for Chinese Strategy, the Hudson Institute, Author of the remarkable book, The Hundred-year Marathon: China's Secret Strategy to Replace America As the Global Superpower, a strategy no longer secret, thanks to his book. Mr. Pillsbury joins us tonight. Thank you very much for coming on. So, this seems like a confirmation, this announcement today, of what we may have known, but still striking.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL PILLSBURY, DIRECTOR OF THE CENTER ON CHINESE STRATEGY
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think when the Director of the FBI calls China our main rival and then specifically said their goal is to replace us as the global superpower, that's the subtitle of my book.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PILLSBURY
utterances.sentences: So, it's not just good news for me though, Tucker. It shows the recognition of the problem of China is now getting quite widespread.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Give us a scale of the hacking efforts by the Chinese government here.

utterances.speaker: PILLSBURY
utterances.sentences: Well they're number one, by far, more than the Russians. They have a number of techniques, some of which were revealed today, formerly classified matters. There's this wonderful term, I hope you'll start using called, Stone Panda. It's the codename for the Chinese unit that's been doing this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Sounds like a restaurant but I like it.

utterances.speaker: PILLSBURY
utterances.sentences: And it seems to - according to this declassified material, it seems to go back 12 years. It seems to focus on American companies. The data that they stole then can help them in negotiations, business negotiations with American companies. They also get trade secrets. It's massive. And it seems to be focused on the high-end technology sectors that China would need to dominate by 2030 or 2035 in order to be the world leader. So, in other words, they're going to steal their way to global leadership, let's put it that way, it's more polite than domination. And the FBI is blowing the whistle today along with the Deputy Attorney General. The PDS (ph), as you may - as you know from the - our local press, there's been a big leak that Steve Mnuchin and the Treasury Department were going to offer sanctions today as punitive for these things that DoJ and the FBI are finding. For some reason, at the last minute, Treasury pulled out, so they weren't (ph) at the announcement and they're not putting the sanctions forward. So, this leak shows dissent inside the Trump team. And, of course, the Chinese have a strategy that Vice President Pence spoke about back in October that they want to divide the Trump Administration. They know they're hawks and doves. So this is a good - this is good news. It's raises public awareness for what China is up to. There were no actual sanctions announced other than the indictment of these two Chinese hackers out of possible 10,000 hackers, let's say.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, there are calls for more Russia sanctions. It just tells you--

utterances.speaker: PILLSBURY
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it just tells you everything. Michael Pillsbury, thank you very much for this and all you've done on this topic.

utterances.speaker: PILLSBURY
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well for more than a month now, France has been wracked by massive riots, the biggest in 50 years. The riots began in response to a planned gasoline tax. Why was the French government raising gasoline taxes? Obviously, climate agenda. Well, in Washington, people only care about Russia, so they've barely noticed this. They think a carbon tax is still a great idea, such a great idea that outgoing Arizona Senator, Jeff Flake, has teamed up with Delaware Democrat, Chris Coons, to introduce a new bill that will impose a nationwide carbon tax. Ethan Bearman is a California radio host and he joins us tonight. Ethan, thanks very much for coming on.

utterances.speaker: ETHAN BEARMAN, LIBERAL RADIO SHOW HOST
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, I think it's pretty clear from what's happening in France that maybe the public globally isn't on board with this because most people care about gas prices because, you know, they don't have their own planes or drivers. So, why would you, in the name of fighting climate change, crush the most vulnerable in your society? That doesn't seem fair.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Well we got two issues that are going on here. First off is in France, Emmanuel Macron, he actually did a massive tax cut on the rich. That's part of what these protests are about. It's not just about the gas tax. It's also the fact that they feel - that people feel like he was just giving away these giant tax cuts to the wealthy. That sounds familiar to the United States. Simultaneously--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, it does.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --the - the U.S. proposal is actually fundamentally different from France. What Senators Flake and Coons put forward is a revenue-neutral carbon tax and dividend, meaning, whatever tax money comes in gets distributed out to the American taxpayer. Now, it will be a progressive--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --no, it will be progressive. So, the lower end of the income (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. So, so, so, we're going to - OK, so we're going to raise--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --the larger your dividend.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --gas taxes and then filter the money through a massive unionized bureaucracy and somehow it'll drip back down to you. But I thought trickle- down economics didn't work. But I guess we're for it now?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, that's not trickle-down economics. Trickle-down economics means tax cut on the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh? I think - I think it kind of is. But it trickles to Republic (ph)--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --everyone (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --employee union first, right? There's a different kind of trickling but it's still - you're still getting wet.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. But - but the difference here is, so we're using a market force to dis-incentivize pollution. Now, one of my big issues with the carbon tax is we can - you can - you can argue all you want about whether or not climate change is man-made or not, but we do know that mercury pollution is a potent neurotoxin. We do know that sulfur pollution has significant--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --health effects. We do know that ground-based ozone, because of our burning of fossil fuels, causes people to die because they can't breathe. I'm a big fan of reducing pollution. If we can use market solutions to incentivize, being more efficient, and dis-incentivize--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --polluting, I think that's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well how about then - then - then look--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --reasonable.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I mean some of this, I - I can't weigh in on one way or another because I'm not a scientist. But I do understand who's getting the short- end of the stick. Wouldn't it be a display of good faith if the people behind this legislation said the first thing we're going to do is ban all private air travel in this country? We're going to (ph) put you in prison if you get on a private plane because - because climate change is that serious. It's an existential threat to the planet, to the human race itself, so like you can't fly on a private plane. And then we'll talk about taxing everybody else like people who make 40 grand. Why not start that way?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: So, we actually agree on the private plane issue. I hate when people will tell me how to live my life and then they do the exact opposite. I can't stand hypocrisy.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, do - do - do you see that happening--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: It's absolutely fence (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --now the politicians who fly constantly private and these actors who fly private and Al Gore who flies private lecturing you--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --about you're suburban. Does that - that is a problem--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: I - I--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --for you then?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm offended by that. I wrote about it in my book, actually--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good for you. But then why not--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --and I specifically pointed out.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --why don't we just ban it?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: It--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, but seriously, if it's that serious a problem, let's just ban it. I mean I don't want to be an authoritarian--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Be--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I was always kind of libertarian. But climate change is too important, OK? So, if you show up at the FBO--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: So, so you don't (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --at the private airport, we're just going to put you in prison.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --so, no. So, I don't - I'm--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --I'm actually a little bit on your side. I don't like banning things.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Guess you're not that serious about climate, are you?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: No. Because here's what happens with the carbon tax, suddenly your private jet, instead of it being $3,000 an hour, because of the tax on your burning of the fossil fuel, will suddenly cost you $5,000 an hour and maybe some of the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I - I guess I just take climate change--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --B-list celebrities will stop flying private.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --a little more seriously than you do. You must be a denier. I just - I don't want to see someone--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm not.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --just spoiling (ph) the earth like that. So, you know, every private plane banned.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Well I again, I don't think we have to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm only half-kidding, sort of--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --ban them, but we - we make it expensive.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: We make it expensive and then--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --then you'll think of twice about doing it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Ethan Bearman, thank you very much. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank - thanks, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well pretty much every college in America, almost every college in America restricts free speech, dramatically. Restricting free speech is, in fact, the signature fact of college, and it's grotesque. Can we do anything about it? That's after the break.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: CAMPUS CRAZINESS.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: America's college campuses were designed to be havens for free expression and for good reason. Free speech is a requirement for free thought. And free thought is central to the idea of universities. There's no other reason to have it. But it's the universities where those ideas, those freedoms are now under the gravest threat. A new report by the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education, FIRE, finds that 90 percent of American college campuses have some kind of speech code that restricts what their students are allowed to say and, by extension, and this is intentional, what's acceptable for them to think. When they can control what you say, they control what you think. Robert Shibley is FIRE's Executive Director and he joins us tonight. Robert, thanks very much for coming on.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT SHIBLEY, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, FIRE
utterances.sentences: Thank--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So--

utterances.speaker: SHIBLEY
utterances.sentences: --thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --when you say there are speech codes, is that strictly speaking? I mean are - are these rules that say you're not allowed to express certain ideas or say certain things or they informal?

utterances.speaker: SHIBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. These are literally formal rules telling you what you can and cannot say on college campuses. And you're right. About 90 percent of them have codes that if it's a public university are unconstitutional or if it is a private university, violates their own promises of free speech. So, FIRE only rates those codes that are written down. If a college is engaging in informal censorship, that's not even part of these ratings.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, I think except for a small handful of colleges, every college in America receives federal funding, every one. So, they would all be subject to the conventional protections, civil rights protection, voting rights. Why are they not required to uphold the First Amendment to the Bill of Rights, freedom of speech?

utterances.speaker: SHIBLEY
utterances.sentences: Well it's interesting. There are some civil rights protections, Title IX, it's probably the most - most well-known one but some--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLEY
utterances.sentences: --racial discrimination as well. Those do come - those are requirements when you get federal funding. But, actually, following the First Amendment is not one of those requirements. We don't make that requirement of colleges who take federal funds. But you're right, it's - it's virtually all of them.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, why wouldn't it be pretty simple for college - for Congress to pass a law saying if you're going to take tax dollars, you have to follow the Bill of Rights? That doesn't seem like a very tough ask.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLEY
utterances.sentences: Well that is something that Congress could do. And it wasn't done back in the - the Civil Rights era. I think now you would see a lot of resistance on political bases because I think people are, you know, there's a lot of support out there, particularly, among college administrators and folks who work at colleges for these kind of restrictions. I think you'd see a lot of opposition to that. I don't think you'd see a lot--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLEY
utterances.sentences: --among your average Americans though.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Man, well if we ever get a Republican Congress maybe they'll do it and, you know, build a wall and stuff like that, protect Americans. Here's hoping. Robert, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLEY
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well Jason Nichols is right in the middle of this debate. He's an actual professor. He teaches African-American studies at the University of Maryland and a frequent guest on this show. Professor, thanks for coming on.

utterances.speaker: JASON NICHOLS, PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND
utterances.sentences: Thank you for having me, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, it seems like kind of a - would be a baseline for a university to have pretty much absolute freedom of speech a prerequisite for freedom of thought like what's the point of having colleges if you can't say whatever you think?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Well I - I think number one, in society, we don't have complete freedom of speech.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Of course, you - you know, there's libel, there's defamation. There is, you know, threats of - of violence and--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --and inciting violence.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Those are limits on free speech. So, I think we have this idea that freedom of speech means that you can say anything at any time.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, no, we know what it is--

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: And it's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --because Brandenburg versus Ohio in 1967, the famous Supreme Court case, very specifically outlined the boundaries of free speech. And so--

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --libel is not allowed, of course. Imminent threats of violence are not allowed. But everything else is allowed. Everything else is allowed. And you would think and - but it's not allowed in Apple or Amazon or some big authoritarian company. But colleges exist to be an oasis in the middle of our commercial society for free thinking. So--

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I - I agree--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --why would they be the places where free thinking is punished most aggressively?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --no, I - I agree that, you know, there - there are many cases. And you and I actually discussed, you know, a - a case a little while ago where there was a college professor who said something he shouldn't have said, and then all of a sudden people are talking about, "Oh, he needs to be fired. Try to," this is why we actually have tenure--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --is, you know, to protect people so that they can say what it is that they want. But there have been all these attacks. There are these people who are trying to put limits on what it is you say. And I think that that's, you know, problematic. But, you know, I think overall colleges do protect freedom of speech. They do protect freedom--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, what would happen if you went in - into your class and say, "Yes (ph), I kind of like that Donald Trump. And what do I like about him? I like the family separation policy, I like the wall. He's right that Mexico doesn't send us its best, just kind of read portions of a Trump speech"--

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --how'd that work out for you?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I don't - I don't - well, I think students would disagree, and they'd have every right to disagree.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course, well, of course, they would. I would never contest their right.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: And - and as a matter of fact, even if they protested me, that's part of their First Amendment right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're not getting - no debate from me on that. I - I believe in the free exchange of ideas. And despite the efforts to shut us down and shut us up, we're - we're still doing it. But if you said that in a faculty meeting, no one would engage you. People would just say, "You know what? You're some - I know you're African- American, but you're obviously some kind of freaky bigot." You know what I mean? They would treat you like they treated Kanye West like no one would engage you and say, let's talk through those ideas. You - you really think the family separation policy is a good idea? No, they would shout at you. Wouldn't you?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Well, I - I think people would disagree. And I think they would have every right to disagree.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, of course, no, but I'm saying--

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: And I - and I think that is--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --like the whole idea of the college is, you say one thing, I say another, then we talk about them to get to wisdom.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Isn't that the goal?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Sure. But I think this - the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But they wouldn't do that (ph).

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --the conversation doesn't always have to be comfortable. That means we--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course, not.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --we can yell at each other, we can sit there and - and try to shut one another down. That's part of free speech.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course, I guess the macro question is have you ever met a group of people with smaller minds than those who teach at America's colleges, less open to new ideas to challenging like truly challenging concepts.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I - I think that's what we literally do on college campuses--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --is challenge concepts and challenge popular ideas. I think number one, you know--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: How about this? Why don't you go to next faculty meeting and say, you know what (ph), just for the record, abortion's murder?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Well let me tell you, hold on, Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I just want to see how that works.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --let me tell you something. Every semester--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --we have abortion activists who come out and litter the campus with pictures of aborted fetuses.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: And there are pregnant women who - who are walking across campus crying and all these kinds of things. It's still their First Amendment right to do that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, of course it is. I'm just saying - I'm just wondering if your college (ph)--

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --and - and nobody (ph) complains.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --but what - people complain.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: People complain, right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But what would your colleagues say if you said that?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: I'm sure they - they'd be disgusted. And they - they'd - they'd be upset with me--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, they would.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --some would, some wouldn't--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They wouldn't be open to like why is it insane (ph)?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: No, they--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What are the ideas behind that?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --they don't have - but they don't have to be open to it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, of course because they're - but they should be because they're not supposed to be small-minded. They're supposed to be broad-minded, but they're not.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: No, these are people who - who are probably studied the issue and they have a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, they haven't. They're dumb people--

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: --a particular view.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --come on.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Oh, they're dumb people. People who study for a living are dumb people.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No. Well, amazingly, that's the irony wrapped in the riddle. You are none of those things, which is why we're so grateful that you come on this show. Thank you, Professor.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Right. Thanks a lot, Tucker. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you. Time now for Final Exam. Can you do better than the news professionals at remembering the news? A lot happened this week. What happened? We don't know. Do you? Find out after the break.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: FINAL EXAM.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh the best and calmest (ph) moment of the week. It's time now for Final Exam where hardened news professionals compete to win an Erik Wemple mug and be crowned the ultimate news champion. This week's exam, we're pitting two of our top Fox News Correspondents against one another, but gently, Lauren Blanchard and Griff Jenkins join us on the set. Griff is a longtime former champion, though I think every match you've won, you had an arm sling on.

utterances.speaker: GRIFF JENKINS, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: We did. We had a four and O (ph) run in a sling. First time the sling came off, I lost.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well we found out recently that Lauren is a very tough competitor, so best of luck to you and, of course, to you.

utterances.speaker: LAUREN BLANCHARD, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right, you know the rules. I'm going to repeat them though for audience at home. Hands on buzzers, I ask the questions. The first one to buzz in gets to answer the question. This is key. You must wait until I finish asking the question in order to answer it. You can answer once I acknowledge you saying your name. Each correct answer is worth a single point. Each incorrect answer detracts a point from your total, the cruel math of Final Exam. Best of five wins. Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I'm ready (ph).

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Good luck.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Good luck, sir.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Let's do it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're going to begin with a multiple-choice question. In a marketing move that is either brilliant or insane, one fast-food chain is now selling fire logs that make your whole house smell like their food. Is the restaurant A, Burger King, B, KFC, C, Domino's? Lauren Blanchard.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It is KFC.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: B, KFC. Boy, you're definitive--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I just hope so (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --on that. Is it KFC?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes. JIMMY KIMMEL, HOST, JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE!: If you are looking to kick-start your Christmas season, you might want to get yourself one of these. This is the KFC 11 herbs and spices--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It's absolutely (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KIMMEL
utterances.sentences: --fire logs. This is the logs that as you get (ph) you put in your fireplace--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: So hard (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KIMMEL
utterances.sentences: --that smells like fried chicken--

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: It's good stuff (ph)--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Well then (ph)--

utterances.speaker: KIMMEL
utterances.sentences: --for real.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It smells like your car in college.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: No, absolutely not. I would - that would not come into my house.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well it sounds like--

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to run down and get one now.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lauren Blanchard, you are up by one point. All right, Griff, it's all you. Question two.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: I agree with you (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Traffic in Los Angeles is notoriously awful. But thanks to the brilliance and the foresight of Elon Musk, relief may be on the way. The billionaire inventor just unveiled what new faster way of getting around Los Angeles? Griff Jenkins.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Tunnel.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Tunnels? Under L.A.?

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: L.A. tunnels.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't believe you. Let's check the tape.

utterances.speaker: GAYLE KING, CO-ANCHOR OF CBS THIS MORNING
utterances.sentences: How about this? Underground tunnels to beat traffic congestion?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Autonomous technology in the cars ensure that they don't run into each other despite going speeds over 125 miles--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: --an hour.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Elon Musk, he's got some bright ideas.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Because when you're near the San Andreas Fault what you want is to drive in a tunnel, don't you think?

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: That would be a little trepidacious to do in there.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: For what it's worth (ph) it's California. They won't even exist. All right, question three, congratulations on that. This week, a man in Missouri was sentenced to a year in prison for illegally poaching hundreds of deer. The Judge also mandated that while the poacher is locked up, he is required to watch which classic Disney movie once a month? Lauren Blanchard.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Bambi.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Bambi?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Bambi.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well that's cool and unusual.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is it Bambi?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: A Judge ordering the man who illegally killed hundreds of deer in Missouri to watch the Disney classic Bambi at least once a month during his one-year jail sentence.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: That's great (ph).

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: That's fantastic.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That man has eaten a lot of venison.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: That is poetic justice there--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Hope he'll change as there (ph)--

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: --terrible was (ph).

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Question four. Another multiple choice, so wait for each option. Forbes this week released its list of the richest celebrities of 2018. The top spot this year went to a filmmaker with a net worth of $5.4 billion. Was it A, George Lucas? Was it B, Steven Spielberg or, C, James Cameron? Lauren Blanchard.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: George Lucas.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: George Lucas. And you're fast--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Star Wars, right?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --with that buzzers.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Right (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is it George Lucas of Star Wars?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Top four U.S., Michael Jordan, Oprah Winfrey, not a surprise--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: --Steven Spielberg. And coming in at number one, Star Wars Creator, George Lucas--

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Ah.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: --with a net worth of $5.4 million.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Billion--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Billion.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: --billion with a B--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Did I say ba, ba, ba--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes (ph).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: --with a B.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Did you know that or did you guess?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: No. I - I - I feel like I knew that one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You feel like you knew that?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: And it's Star Wars. It was a (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: How did you do on the SAT?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Actually, I'm from Michigan. We don't really take the SAT for a- -

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: --lot of Midwest schools, so ACT.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: ACT. I bet you got a 100.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I wish. No, my parents would have been a lot--

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: You have fast - I feel like you're fast (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. No, she's absolutely. She's unbelievable (ph).

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I have - I have two brothers.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: A - a duel draw (ph).

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I've had to fight for a lot of things growing up.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, you can tell. Boy, you are the--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Grumpy (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --you're really first duel (ph). All right, final question.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Which 90s child actor, famous for starring in a very popular Christmas movie, has just reprised his role for a new ad for Google? Lauren.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Macaulay Culkin. I always want to see his--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Macaulay Culkin. Is it--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: --Home Alone.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --Macaulay Culkin?

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is he back?

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACAULAY CARSON CULKIN, ACTOR MUSICIAN
utterances.sentences: Hey, Google, add after-shave--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: It's the Google app (ph).

utterances.speaker: CULKIN
utterances.sentences: --to my shopping list.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: CULKIN
utterances.sentences: Hey Google, remind me to clean these sheets later.

utterances.speaker: GOOGLE
utterances.sentences: OK. I'll remind you.

utterances.speaker: GOOGLE
utterances.sentences: Someone's at the front door.

utterances.speaker: CULKIN
utterances.sentences: What do I owe you?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Looks like you paid online.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Keep the change, you filthy animal.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK, cool.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: It's like (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Amazing.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Our and - well, I don't usually add in a show timer (ph) here but I'm hearing from our judges who would have--

utterances.speaker: CULKIN
utterances.sentences: Hey Google, turn down the temperature two degrees.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --all the metrics in front of them on the Final Exam control room board.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And they're saying that both of you have buzzed in but your reflexes are so lightning quick, you're like a ninja, and they're impressed.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: It is. It's like, you know, the old Western movies where the guy's like--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: --big guns (ph) like that's it. I would never play with you (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Dead before you hit the ground.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Griff, great job.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Congrats.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lauren, congratulations.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Thanks, sir (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And we're going to award you, as we traditionally do, the Erik Wemple mug. He works for Jeff Bezos' website. And we've had some demand--

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --from his relatives for this mug. So, that's how coveted it is. I think they feel the same way as we do about him.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Thanks (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: He's atop, by the way, our Christmas tree. We have an Erik Wemple Christmas tree and I want you to drink your coffee in that every morning and think of us and him.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: I will. I will do that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Great to see you both.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas to both of you.

utterances.speaker: JENKINS
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: BLANCHARD
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's it for tonight's Final Exam. Watch the news closely each night. Tune in every Thursday to see if you can beat the professionals. I don't know if you can. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well CNN just hates it when you call them fake news. The Governor's brother gets all upset. But occasionally, it fits. They promote it. Here's one case. A guy called Claas Relotius was an Investigative Journalist for Der Spiegel. That's the biggest paper in Germany. Couple years ago, CNN honored him as Journalist of the Year. Now, he's being canned. He was caught inventing many of his stories. And it's probably not that surprising. They were absurd stories. One example is his profile of a Minnesota town called Fergus Falls. It had a lot of Trump supporters. So, he went and stayed for a number of weeks to mock them. The article he wrote was full of absurd claims intended to make the residents sound ridiculous. At one point, he said the movie American Sniper was still playing to sold- out crowds two years after it's released. That's how dumb they were in the Trump Town. Well, it took years for him to be caught. One of the main reasons is that he wrote exactly what his audience wanted to hear. And, of course, CNN never noticed. They wanted to hear it too. Author and Columnist Mark Steyn joins us tonight, a longtime fan of Der Spiegel. This guy was kind of hiding in plain sight.

utterances.speaker: MARK STEYN, COLUMNIST, STEYNONLINE.COM
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is a very traditional kind of story that Europeans and people of what one might call a Eurocentric bent such as CNN enjoy. They - they like to send their reporters out into the great wastelands of the American interior and report back that all the people there are inbred, stump-truth (ph), snake-handling crazies, who like nothing better than a jigger of moonshine and a bunk up (ph) with their sister before they go down--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, God (ph).

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --to have their church renamed after Trump and do a couple of scripture readings from The Art of the Deal. So, basically--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Ha-ha. Ha-ha.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --this - this guy, no, you laugh - you laugh, Tucker. But that is actually what these newspapers and magazines won. And they're prepared to give you awards for it, like this guy got Journalist of the Year. A guy called Matthew Engel at The Guardian, his - his editors told him to go a - to the most backward parts of America and find the most inbred crazies to write about. And his heart wasn't really in it. So, he went to a suburban Olive Garden restaurant and wrote it up as if he was Stanley in Africa discovering Livingstone. That's how they think of the interior of America. This guy was completely ridiculous. He says the Town Manager was a virgin who had never been to the ocean and these guys in Fergus Falls post the photograph of the Town Manager standing on the ocean shore with the woman he lives with. I mean this - this guy got there, discovered the story wasn't there, but decided to write it for his readers anyway.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Can I just quick - super - super quick--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: And that is a lot of what news is about.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --when I first met you and you were writing for about five different English newspapers. You've been a newspaper man--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --a journalist for many years.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, you know the answer. Do you think journalists are getting dumber or is it just my imagination?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Oh, no. I think they - I think the herd mentality of all like sitting around in the Washington Bureau or whatever, and - and the idea of actually all agreeing on the net - I think the groupthink, the herd mentality is far worse than it was 20 or 40 years ago.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Good. Thank you. I needed a reality check. The great Mark Steyn, thanks a lot. It's fantastic.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Tucker, merry Christmas to you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: SHIP OF FOOLS.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well the current battle over border wall funding says everything about the state of modern American leadership. Washington easily agrees on funding an endless war in Afghanistan, giving aid to foreign countries, handing tax breaks to powerful tech monopolies. But protect America's sovereignty, help actual Americans secure the border? Whoa, agreement is completely impossible. How'd that happen? Well, for a blueprint, there's a new book called Ship of Fools: How a Selfish Ruling Class Is Bringing America to the Brink of the Revolution. That title was formulated about a year ago. It seems more accurate than ever, sadly. Anyway, pretty good Christmas present if you got someone who wants to be informed but depressed. That's about it for us tonight. We are out of time. What a fun hour that was? We'll hope you see it tomorrow night 8:00 P.M., the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and groupthink. Five days till Christmas. So, time to buy some presents. Good night from Washington. Hannity's next. Dan Bongino, sitting in for Sean for a second night and--

utterances.speaker: DANIEL JOHN BONGINO, FORMER SECRET SERVICE AGENT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --that's a good sign. Hey, Dan.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, isn't it? It's like a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: --Dan Bongino double-header or something, Tucker. I'll be with you tomorrow night, as a matter of fact so.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I can't wait.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Back from the home studio--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Have a great hour.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: --in the bunker. Thanks a lot, Tucker, great show as always.
